content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION is added to the Consumer Credit Protection Act to enhance financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act, under Title X of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, includes sections on short title, definitions, privacy protection for customer information, enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalty, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Financial Information Privacy Act, also known as the 'Financial Information Privacy Act', defines key terms such as 'customer' and 'customer information of a financial institution'. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines terms related to customer information of a financial institution, including customer, document, and financial institution. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines terms related to customer information of a financial institution, including customer, document, and financial institution. A financial institution holds any information derived from its relationship with a customer and identified with the customer, in any form. Financial institution refers to any institution providing financial services to customers with a credit, deposit, trust, or other financial account. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines a financial institution as any institution providing financial services to customers with a credit, deposit, trust, or other financial account. This includes depository institutions, loan or finance companies, and credit card issuers. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines a financial institution broadly, including depository institutions, loan or finance companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has the authority to further define financial institutions through regulations. The Financial Information Privacy Act broadly defines financial institutions, including depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. Regulations can be prescribed to further define the term "financial institution" for this title. The Privacy Protection for Customer Information of Financial Institutions prohibits obtaining customer information through false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as making false statements to deceive officers or customers. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as making false statements to deceive officers or customers by knowingly providing false information. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits deceiving customers of a financial institution by making fraudulent statements or providing forged documents with the intent to obtain customer information. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits the use of forged, counterfeit, or fraudulent documents to deceive financial institution employees into releasing customer information. It is also illegal to solicit someone to obtain customer information under false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits using false documents to deceive financial institutions into releasing customer information. It is also illegal to solicit individuals to obtain customer information under false pretenses. Law enforcement agencies are exempt from these provisions. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from financial institutions through deceptive means. Law enforcement agencies and certain financial institutions are exempt from these provisions. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits deceptive means to obtain customer information from financial institutions. However, certain exemptions allow financial institutions to access customer information for security testing and misconduct investigations. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows exemptions for financial institutions to access customer information for security testing, misconduct investigations, and customer information recovery. The Financial Information Privacy Act exempts financial institutions from restrictions when accessing customer information for security testing, misconduct investigations, and customer information recovery. Administrative enforcement is covered under Section 1004. Financial Institutions are not restricted from accessing customer information available as public records under the securities laws. Administrative enforcement under Section 1004 is enforced by the Federal Trade Commission. Administrative enforcement of compliance with this title is carried out by the Federal Trade Commission, with the same power as under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In certain cases, enforcement can also be done by other agencies such as the Federal Deposit Insurance Act for national banks and Federal branches. Enforcement of compliance with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act can be done by the Federal Trade Commission or other agencies like the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks and Federal branches. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency oversees national banks, while the Board regulates member banks of the Federal Reserve System and other financial institutions. The Board oversees Federal branches, Federal agencies, State branches of foreign banks, commercial lending companies owned by foreign banks, and organizations operating under the Federal Reserve Act. It also regulates banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and insured State branches of foreign banks. The Board oversees banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, including savings associations with insured deposits. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation oversees branches of foreign banks, savings associations with insured deposits, and violations of this title are treated as violations of the Federal Credit Union Act. The Office of Thrift Supervision and the National Credit Union Administration oversee financial institutions, and violations of this title are considered violations of other related laws. Agencies can enforce compliance with this title using their existing powers and authorities. States also have the authority to take action against violations. Each agency mentioned in paragraph (1) can use their existing authority to enforce compliance with this title. States can also take legal action to stop violations of this title. The State must serve prior written notice of any action to the Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies, providing a copy of the complaint, except when prior notice is not feasible. The State must provide prior written notice of any action to the Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies, allowing them the right to intervene in the action. The Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies have the right to intervene in actions, be heard on all matters, remove actions to the appropriate court, and file petitions for appeal. If the Federal Trade Commission or any agency has initiated a civil action for a violation of this title, no State can bring a separate action against the same defendant for the same violation while the federal action is ongoing. Civil liability is addressed in Section 1005. "During a federal action for a violation of this title, no State can bring a separate action against the same defendant. Civil liability for non-compliance with this title is outlined in Section 1005." Any person failing to comply with this title regarding a financial institution or customer information is liable for actual damages sustained by the institution or customer. The liability for failing to comply with financial institution or customer information includes actual damages, additional damages as allowed by the court, and attorneys' fees for successful cases. Sec. 1006. Criminal penalty: Whoever violates section 1003 may be fined or imprisoned for up to 5 years. Sec. 1006 outlines the criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines and imprisonment for up to 5 years. Additionally, enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving other illegal activities or significant financial amounts. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases of violating section 1003, including fines up to twice the amount specified in section 3571 of title 18, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. The title does not supersede state laws. Sec. 1007 of the title clarifies that state laws remain in effect unless they conflict with this title, in which case the inconsistency is addressed. Sec. 1008 of the title addresses agency guidance from Federal banking agencies to further the objectives of the title. Sec. 1008 of this title requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to depository institutions to prevent prohibited activities under section 1003. The agencies must ensure that the protection provided by any statute, regulation, order, or interpretation does not exceed the protection under this title. Additionally, a report to Congress must be submitted within 18 months of the enactment of this Act by the Comptroller. Before the end of the 18-month period, the Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress on the effectiveness of the remedies provided in deterring and detecting prohibited activities in depository institutions. The General, in consultation with relevant agencies, will report to Congress on the effectiveness of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and recommend legislative actions to protect financial privacy.
